item.title: Random number
item.dc:creator: @Disorder Disorder
item.description:
@Disorder wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:18, topic:444734”]You realize signum is doing the exact same thing as what veer just posted, except less efficient, right?

[quote author=Disorder link=topic=547421.msg4013744#msg4013744 date=1339450698]

Because only the cool kids use negative array indices

His suggestion was general. Or was it really a “real manly” rounding method for positive floating point numbers only?
[/quote]He was being funny. Calm down. They were all talking about positive integers (specifically, array indices), read the rest of the thread.[/quote]

Do you realize that I was making fun of you guys? That’s the reason for these “real manly” methods.

The principle is that Math.round() should be used. When you start reinventing rounding based on exceptional situations, it’s bad coding practice.

Be more precise about what you say. Signum extracts the sign. veer posted a rounding function. Not the same. However signum was a part of a function that performed rounding.

Are you really talking about efficiency here? Especially when the topic relates to the horribly slow language called java. But let’s continue. Did you know that branching (ternary operator) is less efficient than multiplication? Java’s Math.signum() just happens to be bad. There are very fast branchless ways to extract a sign.

Read full topic

item.title: Random number
item.dc:creator: @Disorder Disorder
item.description:
@Disorder wrote:

Davidi2:

Because only the cool kids use negative array indices

His suggestion was general. Or was it really a “real manly” rounding method for positive floating point numbers only?

Also here’s a “real manly” correct rounding method, incase any of you would like to use it. Of course only use it when you’re not sure whether the number is negative or positive. If you’re convinced it’s negative use -0.5F, if you’re convinced it’s positive use +0.5F. That’s a total of three cases, using them appropriately throughout your code makes your code look amazing.

final float a = -1.49F;
final int a = (int) (a + Math.signum(a) * 0.5F);

Or you could just use Math.round() and quit being a fool.

Read full topic

item.title: Random number
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

[quote=“Disorder, post:14, topic:444734”][quote author=t4 link=topic=547421.msg4013682#msg4013682 date=1339447100]
as Method said, rounding is bad in this case; however, real men round by adding 0.5F and casting.
[/quote]

You mean real stupid people?

public class Main 
{
	public static void main(String[] args)
	{
		final float a = -1.0F;
		final int b = (int) (a + 0.5F);
		final int c = Math.round(a);
		
		System.out.println(a); // -1.0
		System.out.println(b); // 0
		System.out.println(c); // -1 CORRECT
	}
}

I think you should change your “real manly” coding practises.[/quote]

The trick he mentioned was for non-negative integers.

static int round(float f) {
    return (int) (f < 0 ? f - 0.5 : f + 0.5); 
}

That being said, Math.random() returns a double, so the method would be a bit different.

Read full topic

item.title: Random number
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

class DieRollSimulator {

    static class Die {

        private static final int[] FACES = new int[] { 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 };

        private final Random rand = new Random();

        int roll() {
            return FACES[rand.nextInt(6)];
        }
    }

    public static void main(String[] argv) {
        Die die = new Die();
        System.out.println("Jamie rolls the die and gets a: " + die.roll());
    }
}

Read full topic

item.title: Random number
item.dc:creator: @Metho_D Method
item.description:
@Metho_D wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:3, topic:444734”][quote author=Native^ link=topic=547421.msg4013600#msg4013600 date=1339442157]
Math.random() * RandomNumber.length
[/quote]
Math.round(Math.random() * RandomNumber.length)

Rounding is important[/quote]

Not in this case. If Math.random() gives you 0.99, for example, then 0.99 * 5 = 4.95, which will be rounded to 5. 5 isn’t a valid array index.

You want to use (int) (Math.random() * RandomNumber.length) or, alternatively, the nextInt() method of the Random class to index into the array.

Read full topic

item.title: Random number
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Native^, post:4, topic:444734”][quote author=eyeownyew link=topic=547421.msg4013603#msg4013603 date=1339442266]

Math.random() * RandomNumber.length

Math.round(Math.random() * RandomNumber.length)

Rounding is important
[/quote]
It will be automatically rounded when you upcast to integer. Won’t it?[/quote]
Nope. It’s truncated. The result would be the first number in the series. However:

public static int round(float a) Returns the closest int to the argument. The result is rounded to an integer by adding 1/2, taking the floor of the result, and casting the result to type int.

Read full topic

item.title: Random number
item.dc:creator: @Native1 Native^
item.description:
@Native1 wrote:

Math.random() * RandomNumber.length

The random() method creates a double precision number between 0 and 1 (so 0.1234, 0.1111, 0.999 etc.), then multiply it with the length of the array (0.34 * 5 = 1.7) will be rounded to 2, so that’s the value 2 in the array.

Read full topic
